Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Dynamics in Rapidly Evolving Populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolution is one of the most fundamental processes in biology, but it can be notoriously difficult to observe directly. Evolutionary change accumulates over many thousands of generations as a result of a relentless competition between different genetic variants in a population. Except in a few rare cases, the intermediate steps of this competition are only partially preserved in the fossil record or the diversity of present-day species. This makes it hard to obtain the empirical data necessary for building and testing theories about the adaptive process. The present work aims to fill this void by constructing a high-resolution 'molecular fossil record' documenting 60,000 generations of evolution in experimental populations of bacteria. The unique duration of this experiment --- almost a quarter of the time since the human-chimpanzee split --- allows one to directly observe how the tempo of molecular evolution changes over long evolutionary timescales, and the biological replication will show which aspects of this process change when the evolutionary tape is replayed. These data will play a key role in testing existing theories of adaptation in a constant environment, and will help suggest new ways to model the evolution of large microbial populations.

To achieve these goals, this study will leverage new experimental techniques for massively multiplexed DNA sequencing to measure genetic diversity in the frozen ``fossil record'' of a well-studied evolution experiment in Escherichia coli. Combined with new bioinformatic techniques, these regularly preserved, whole-population samples allow one to trace the trajectories of new mutations as they arise and compete for dominance in the population. The ?molecular fossil records? that emerge from this analysis will constitute the longest and most detailed view of the dynamics of molecular evolution in any natural or experimental population. They will also generate a wealth of genetic data that will be used to compare patterns of molecular convergence and parallelism across populations and through time. These new measurements will be combined with a recently developed computational framework in order to test long-standing theoretical predictions about the dynamics of evolution in a constant environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite the fundamental role that evolution plays throughout biology, it can be a notoriously difficult process to observe directly. Evolutionary change accumulates over many thousands of generations as a by-product of the relentless competition between different genetic variants in a population. Except in a few rare cases, the intermediate steps of this competition are only partially preserved in the fossil record or in the diversity of present-day species. This makes it hard to obtain the empirical data necessary for testing theoretical predictions about how populations adapt to their surroundings.

The present work is an attempt to bridge this data gap. By sequencing DNA from frozen samples in Richard Lenski's long-term evolution experiment (the LTEE), we have constructed a series of high-resolution “molecular fossil records” documenting 60,000 generations of evolution in replicate populations of E. coli. To do so, we combined advances in massively multiplexed DNA sequencing with a novel bioinformatic pipeline that we have developed in order to trace the trajectories of new mutations as they compete for dominance in the population. This dataset provides the first truly long-term view of the population genetics of adaptation in a fixed environment, covering a timescale almost two orders of magnitude longer than comparable sequencing studies in yeast, bacteria, or viruses. The unique duration of this experiment (in generations, almost a quarter of the time since the human-chimpanzee split) allows us to directly observe how the tempo of molecular evolution changes over long evolutionary timescales, and the biological replication enables us to see which aspects of this process change when the evolutionary tape is replayed. Together, these data provide new insights into the long-term dynamics of evolution in a constant environment.

We find that, while the rate of fitness improvement in the LTEE has dramatically slowed over time, the rate of molecular evolution continues to proceed a very rapid pace, even after tens of thousands of generations (and nearly 100 substitutions). On shorter timescales, the population genetic process is characterized by widespread clonal interference, in which multiple beneficial mutations compete for dominance in the population at the same time. Our whole-population sequencing strategy is particularly powerful in this case, since it can uncover outcompeted adaptive mutations in addition to those that eventually fix. The time-resolved mutation trajectories also reveal other features of the evolutionary dynamics which are not immediately apparent from previous phenotypic measurements. For example, we observe several instances of the spontaneous generation of competitive coexistence, in which subtypes appear to be stable in the short-term but are subject to large fluctuations on longer timescales due to feedback between ecological and evolutionary processes. These findings pose a challenge for existing population genetic models of adaptation, in which the formation of distinct ecotypes is assumed to be rare.

In summary, the reconstructed “molecular fossil records'' paint a surprisingly complex picture of evolution for one of nature's simplest organisms in one of its simplest possible environments. Far from the evolutionary desert expected near a fitness optimum, we find that long-term adaptation to a constant environment is characterized by a rich and dynamic population genetic process, even after tens of thousands of generations have elapsed. These findings highlight the use of time-resolved genetic data to uncover aspects of adaptation that are difficult to observe directly, and will help suggest new ways to model the evolution of large microbial populations.
